problem: Six construction workers that work at the same rate can build a house in 1.5 days.  How long does it take 15 construction workers, working at the same rate, to finish building a house?  Express your answer as a fraction in lowest terms.
solution: The number of workers is inversely proportional to the amount of time it takes to build a house.  Thus $$\text{number of workers} \times \text{time} = \text{constant}.$$Using this, we have that $6 \cdot 1.5 = 15 \cdot t \Rightarrow t = .6$.  As a fraction in lowest terms this is $\boxed{\frac{3}{5}}$.
model_solution:
Let x = time needed for 15 construction workers to finish building a house.

Six workers can build a house in 1.5 days, so 1 worker can build a house in (1.5)(6) = 9 days.

15 workers can build a house in (9)/15 = (3)/5 days.
x = (3)/5
x = \frac{3}{5}
x = (3)/5

full_steps:
Let x = time needed for 15 construction workers to finish building a house.

Six workers can build a house in 1.5 days, so 1 worker can build a house in (1.5)(6) = 9 days.

15 workers can build a house in (9)/15 = (3)/5 days.
